editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: INTRODUCTION.
div.p: SOME things which were but ju≈øt touched, or con≈øidered only in a general way, in the examination of Mr. Edwards, require a further and particular examination: And other things need a more di≈øtinct explanation: His denial of moral, rational liberty; his di≈øtinction of natural and moral nece≈ø≈øity; attributing the origin of evil to the want or withdraw of divine a≈ø≈øi≈øtance; ≈øeperating the obliquity of ≈øin from its cau≈øe; are ≈øome of the points that require a further examination. And tho≈øe that need a more di≈øtinct explanation are the doctrine of human liberty as maintained by the examiner, and the con≈øi≈øtency thereof with admitting the operation of motives in the choice and determinations of moral agents.

The examiner hath the ≈øame opinion ≈øtill of the intricacy of the ≈øubject as was expre≈ø≈øed in his former publication, and means to proceed in it with caution and diffidence. If he may be ≈øo happy as to ca≈øt any light on the ab≈øtru≈øe ≈øubject of liberty and nece≈ø≈øity, or re≈øcue it in any important re≈øpect from its ob≈øcurity, his time will not be ill-employed. But the main thing in view all along has been to vindicate the moral character of the Deity from the injurious repre≈øentations, either of de≈øigning, or well-meaning but mi≈øtaken men.

The ≈øcheme of nece≈ø≈øity, in oppo≈øition to ≈øelf-determination, cannot, he thinks, be defended on the principles of revelation or thei≈øm, if this one thing be admitted, that God is not the cau≈øe of moral evil. If it be affirmed, that he is the efficient cau≈øe of it, his moral perfections are denied. If moral agents them≈øelves are the efficient cau≈øe, this is to admit ≈øelf-determination.

Some maintain only an hypothetic liberty. On their principles nece≈ø≈øity may be tenable‚Äîprovided there is neither holine≈øs nor ≈øin in the creation of God‚Äîno being worthy of moral complacence or di≈øplicence, prai≈øe or blame.

The examiner begs the reader to keep in mind this ≈øingle que≈øtion, Whether Mr. Edwards's doctrine makes God the efficient cau≈øe of all moral wickedne≈øs? He is him≈øelf clear in the affirmative of the que≈øtion, or would not have undertaken to examine Mr. Edwards's book. If this ≈øhould al≈øo be the reader's opinion, it is pre≈øum'd the ≈øcheme which contains or concludes in this will be rejected. To reduce a Chri≈øtian writer to this is ≈øufficient, without going any further. Nor will there be occa≈øion to ≈øhew how different ≈øuch a ≈øcheme is from the ≈øentiments of tho≈øe who have been e≈øteemed orthodox in the pure≈øt times of the church: It is with no great propriety, that Mr. Edwards makes it the caption of almo≈øt every ≈øection, that his foundation principles are the doctrines of Calvini≈øm; and the oppo≈øite Arminiani≈øm. Pelagiani≈øm, &c. Were it indeed ≈øo, what other purpo≈øe can this ≈øerve than to ca≈øt an odium, and fix a per≈øonal ≈øtigma? But in truth, when have Calvini≈øts maintain'd, that the vicious wills of moral agents are derived from God, and unalterably fixed by his efficiency? that the fir≈øt exi≈øtence of ≈øin aro≈øe from the witholding his influence and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance? Should it al≈øo appear that Mr. Edwards's doctrine leaves no room for a di≈øtinction between rational and animal creatures in re≈øpect of liberty and agency‚Äîthat it concludes in favour of the mechani≈øm of the human mind, this is a ba≈øis on which Calvini≈øts have not built their ≈øcheme of doctrine.

In ≈øome parts of the en≈øuing performance, the examiner hath been obliged to be more ab≈øtru≈øe than was his own choice; ≈øome readers might otherwi≈øe have thought him
wanting in re≈øpect to Mr. Edwards, who≈øe book is repleat with ≈øuch rea≈øoning; abundant pains being taken this way to deduce his adver≈øaries to ab≈øurdity. But whatever propriety there may be in oppo≈øing metaphy≈øics to metaphy≈øics, yet the examiner would a≈ø≈øure the reader, he hath taken care not to ≈øub≈øtitute any metaphy≈øics of his own for truth; but hath endeavoured to ≈øugge≈øt ≈øome plain things on what he takes to be the real truth in the pre≈øent debate. He de≈øires the reader would excu≈øe a few things that may appear ab≈øtru≈øe, and hopes the greater part of what he hath written will be thought ≈øufficiently clear, and adapted to do ≈øome good. The whole calls for the public candor, which he would not forfeit by writing with a ≈øour temper.

He hath not been at all intimidated by the opinion or arguments of his remarker, who thinks the grand pillars of Mr. Edwards's doctrine ≈øtand firm and un≈øhaken. Nor hath he any apology to make for undertaking to examine Mr. Edwards's book. Tis enough, that the examiner treated "this great man" with no di≈ørepect in his fir≈øt publication, and determines not to in the pre≈øent.

div.head: SECTION I. On Self-determination.
div.p: WE ≈øhall fir≈øt explain the doctrine of human liberty in the ≈øen≈øe in which we maintain it. Secondly, Make a few cur≈øory ob≈øervations on Mr. Edwards's ≈øcheme of liberty.

Power, motion and agency are terms of various ≈øignification. The two fir≈øt are frequently u≈øed in mechanics, and all of them may be applied to animal creatures. "Power may re≈øide in a ≈øubject that is no agent; as in the ca≈øe of phy≈øical or natural powers."

When we ≈øpeak of the motions and revolutions of inanimate bodies, it may amount to the ≈øame thing at la≈øt, whether we attribute the≈øe to an e≈øtabli≈øhed original law of nature, or to the con≈øtant agency of the Deity upon matter. The cour≈øe of nature is the con≈øtitution of the author of nature. It is demon≈øtrably not ≈øo fixed as to preclude ≈øpecial divine interpo≈øition, whereby the operation of ≈øecond cau≈øes is ≈øu≈øpended or counteracted. We cannot, indeed, determine how far this is the ca≈øe. Many events may be brought about (at lea≈øt in part) by ≈øecond cau≈øes, which we may imagine belong to the head of ≈øpecial interpo≈øitions, over-ruling tho≈øe cau≈øes. 'Tis difficult to a≈øcertain the powers of nature, as well as tho≈øe of moral agents.

There is a ≈øen≈øe in which there is no power but of God. And if any chu≈øe to ≈øay, that natural cau≈øes (≈øo called) are really no cau≈øe at all; that God actuates all the powers of nature, and that from his energy every effect in the natural world proceeds, we have no objection to make. We only de≈øire it may be remembered, that mechanic powers, the motions of inanimate bodies, bear no re≈øemblance to, and give us no idea of, the powers of moral and accountable
creatures. Shou'd one undertake to illu≈øtrate con≈øciou≈øne≈øs by the vibrations of a pendulum, it would not be more ridiculous than a pretence to explain the powers of human nature by the motions of the planets, the growth of vegetables, &c. The≈øe are ≈øo far from being any exemplification of moral agency, that they bear no likene≈øs even to animal motion. For this is voluntary. And we pre≈øume it will not be ≈øaid that voluntary motion is predicable of inanimate things‚Äînot even by tho≈øe philo≈øophers who have re≈øembled the powers of moral nature to tho≈øe of material bodies.

Nor will the con≈øideration of animal motion and agency, any more than the motions of inanimate bodies, afford us any proper illu≈øtration of moral agency. Voluntary motion and exertion is indeed common to moral agents and the lower animals. The≈øe have natural power, foreca≈øte, memory, can move this way or that as they plea≈øe, or according to the determination of their will. They are agents‚Äî voluntary agents‚Äî'Tis apparent they "act electively"‚Äî from de≈øign‚Äîto certain ends. They are capable of being taught many things. From the ≈øagacity ≈øome of them di≈øcover, many have conjectur'd that they have an immortal ≈øpirit, and are accountable. This, we apprehend, is going too far, and find Mr. Edwards concurs with us.P. 41. Whatever gradations there are in the creation, mankind appear to be the lowe≈øt order of intelligent moral agents. The appearances of rea≈øon in many of the brute creatures are ea≈øily accounted for without ≈øuppo≈øing them po≈ø≈øe≈øs'd of a moral faculty‚Äîin much the ≈øame manner as we account for many in≈øtances of the conduct of ideots, who never had the exerci≈øe of this faculty; of madmen, who have lo≈øt it; and of children before they arrive to the exerci≈øe of it. What they ≈øee and experience from day to day affords them in≈øtruction, and influenceth their conduct, without their having any perception of good and evil in a moral view. The ≈øame holds, in a degree, in the inferior creatures. The ox knoweth his owner, and the a≈øs his ma≈øter's crib. And tho≈øe animals, who have no guide, over≈øeer or ruler, give proofs of ≈øagacity and foreca≈øte, the con≈øideration of which wou'd be of
u≈øe to many who have rea≈øon for their guide. The animal creatures are al≈øo the ≈øubjects of certain internal di≈øpo≈øitions and affections. They have a common care and tenderne≈øs for their young. Some of the feebler ≈øort a≈ø≈øociate for the double purpo≈øe of protection and common u≈øefulne≈øs. Some kinds of them are of a fierce, venomous, or ravenous di≈øpo≈øition; others are mild, gentle and harmle≈øs. "Spontaneous voluntary exertion" belongs to every ≈øpecies of them. But though ≈øpontaneous animal motion may approach the neare≈øt to moral agency, of any thing in vi≈øible nature; yet it is e≈ø≈øentially different thereform, nor doth it give us any proper idea thereof. A ju≈øt notion of moral agency we can derive only from attending to the nature and operations of the human mind‚Äînot from a contemplation of inanimate or animate nature. The in≈øpiration of the Almighty hath given us under≈øtanding. I will prai≈øe thee; for I am fearfully and wonderfully made; marvellous are thy works, and that my ≈øoul knoweth right well. God created man in his own image.

It ≈øeems, notwith≈øtanding, that ≈øome gentlemen need to be inform'd, that man hath a di≈øtinctive power from animals. We ≈øcruple not to ri≈øque the whole controver≈øy on their being able to point out a difference, ≈øtill retaining their own principles.

Hard is our ta≈øk to be obliged to explain the difference between a man and a brute in regard of liberty and ≈øelf-determination. Such minds as acknowledge no difference, we fear cannot be convinc'd. In regard to truths we are immediately con≈øcious of, every medium of proof, all rea≈øoning, not only ≈øeems needle≈øs, but rather ≈øerves to ob≈øcure than elucidate what is propo≈øed to be proved. As tho' by removing the object to a greater di≈øtance, we wou'd obtain a more di≈øtinct and full view of it.

The di≈øtinctive faculty of moral agents we before endeavoured to ≈øtate and explain‚Äîand we think it was ≈øhewn, that moral liberty really differs from animal, and that, "in finite beings placed upon trial, it implies an opportunity and capacity of chu≈øing and acting otherwi≈øe than they in fact do."Examination of Edwards, Part III. Sect. I. Further to illu≈øtrate and confirm the
≈øame thing, we de≈øire the capacity moral agents have of examining and con≈øidering before they make their choice, or proceed to act, in any given ca≈øe, may be well attended to. They can determine to con≈øider the rea≈øonablene≈øs or unrea≈øonablene≈øs of any propo≈øed object of choice‚Äîwhether it be con≈øi≈øtent with, or contrary to, their duty‚Äîwhether it be for their intere≈øt upon the whole‚Äîand con≈øequently, whether it is the part of wi≈ødom to chu≈øe or refu≈øe it. They have this power in regard to ≈øpeculative principles, as well as with re≈øpect to life and conduct. They can examine the nature and evidence of what is propo≈øed to 'm for truth, and embrace or reject it as it ≈øhall appear to be true or fal≈øe upon diligent and impartial enquiry; or give it that weight which its greater or le≈øs importance ≈øhall demand. Error in principle is one great ≈øource of men's practical deviations from the paths of righteou≈øne≈øs. Hence it is, not infrequently, that they ju≈øtify and boa≈øt them≈øelves in a way that is not good, imagining they are doing God ≈øervice, when in reality they are fighting again≈øt him. Now ≈øo far as men judge wrong, and in con≈øequence thereof act wrong, thro' their own carele≈ø≈øne≈øs, or neglect, or through partiality in their enquiries after truth; ≈øo far they are criminal, and chargeable with all the practical con≈øequences of their wrong judgment. If the mi≈øtakes of mankind on practical ≈øubjects are ≈øearched to the bottom, the probability is, that the greater part of ≈øuch mi≈øtakes will be found to proceed from that cau≈øe our Lord mentions, Every one that doeth evil, hateth the light, neither cometh to the light, lo≈øt his deeds ≈øhou'd be reproved. And this is their condemnation. For what hath that man to plead, who receives not the love of the truth, becau≈øe he hath plea≈øure in unrighteou≈øne≈øs? From whatever cau≈øe men refu≈øe to examine the foundation and rea≈øonablene≈øs of tho≈øe religious principles they profe≈øs to maintain, or reject; whether it be from education, intere≈øt, or partial affection; they are criminal, and mu≈øt an≈øwer it to him who has given them a capacity to di≈øcern the difference between right and wrong, good and evil‚Äîwho has granted them the nece≈ø≈øary means of knowledge, and requires that they prove all things; and hold fa≈øt that which
is good‚Äîthat they judge even of them≈øelves what is right. Had that rule, which ≈øome have laid down to them≈øelves and others, "fir≈øt determine and then examine," been univer≈øally adopted, knowledge cou'd never have increa≈øed‚Äî ignorance, ≈øuper≈øtition and barbari≈øm mu≈øt have over≈øpread the earth.

Then in matters which more immediately re≈øpect the heart and life, moral agents have the ≈øame power of examining and attending to what is laid before them. Mo≈øt of their vicious elections and pur≈øuits probably proceed from want of attention and con≈øideration. They have a power of reflecting‚Äîof acquainting them≈øelves which is the wi≈øe choice and cour≈øe. But they do not ≈øtop and con≈øider what is before them‚Äîwhat choice they are about to make‚Äîwhat will be the con≈øequence in this world or another. Their conclu≈øions are precipitate, and they proceed to action as the hor≈øe ru≈øheth into the battle. What ≈øtrikes their external ≈øen≈øes, and promi≈øes a pre≈øent gratification to their particular affections, lu≈øts or pa≈ø≈øions, is wont to be greedily embrac'd and pur≈øued‚Äîwhat requires ≈øome ≈øelf-denial and mortification of the≈øe is quickly rejected, before that faculty, which is naturally ≈øupream, and was given to direct and controul the bodily appetites, in≈øtincts and pa≈ø≈øions, can pa≈øs judgment in the ca≈øe. Wrong apprehen≈øions, wrong affections and conduct, proceeding in ≈øo many in≈øtances as they manife≈øtly do from the neglect of rea≈øon and reflection, ≈øhew of what va≈øt importance it is that moral agents ≈øet down and con≈øider before they pa≈øs judgment, or make their election, and determine what cour≈øe to take, in things that concern them. Experience concurs with the ≈øacred oracles in atte≈øting, that the want of attention and examination is a principal ≈øource of the fatal mi≈øtakes and mi≈øcarriages of mankind: And how cou'd it be expected it ≈øhou'd be otherwi≈øe, when the regulating faculty of our nature, in≈øtead of being improv'd in the ≈øearch of truth and duty, is u≈øed, if at all, as a ≈øervant to the ≈øen≈øitive appetites? This is a like contradiction in morals as it is in civil life to ≈øee ≈øervants on hor≈øes, and princes walking like ≈øervants on the earth‚Äîor as if the feet ≈øhould u≈øurp the place of the head in the natural body.

When in any given ca≈øe it is dubious what cour≈øe is our duty to take, or wou'd be mo≈øt prudent all things con≈øidered, by deliberating on the matter we may come to be clearly ≈øatisfied; whereas if we proceed immediately to action, we are liable to err fatally‚Äîand ≈øhou'd it be otherwi≈øe, we can't have the plea≈øure of knowing that we are right‚Äî'tis accidental that we are ≈øo‚Äîwe merit no commendation, but rather de≈øerve blame for runing the hazard of being in the wrong, when we might have obtained full conviction had we been at the pains, and given our≈øelves time, to reflect a few moments.

Or ≈øuppo≈øe the ≈øen≈øe of duty is ≈øufficiently clear, but we are be≈øet by numerous and powerful temptations, have we not power to make a pau≈øe? By this means, we may obtain ≈øuch a view of the particular evil to which we are enticed, ≈øuch con≈øiderations may be ≈øugge≈øted to our minds, as that a pre≈øent temptation, however ≈øtrong, ≈øhall not prevail, but gradually loo≈øe ≈øtrength and be overcome. Will you ≈øay that men in this ca≈øe have not power to forbear immediate action? to reflect a moment? Doubtle≈øs they have power to determine immediately with them≈øelves to con≈øider the matter. E≈øpecially mu≈øt they be admitted to have this power, if we take into the account the operations of divine grace on their hearts. In this way many good tho'ts are often injected in the moment of danger. May they not be cheri≈øh'd, and made our own? By reflections on the nature of virtue and vice; their rewards and puni≈øhments pre≈øent and future; the pa≈øt peaceable and happy fruits of the one; and contrary effects of the other, in our own experience, or ob≈øervation of others; by reflections on the moral perfections and government of God; the per≈øon and offices of Je≈øus Chri≈øt, and calling to mind other con≈øiderations ≈øugge≈øted by the oracles of truth, the force of a pre≈øent temptation may be ≈øpeedily weakned thro' the influences of grace ≈øugge≈øting and concuring with ≈øuch moral con≈øiderations. While the force of con≈øcience is abated by ≈øtifling it's remon≈øtrances, and hearkning to the ≈øollicitations of lu≈øt and appetite in oppo≈øition thereto; it's ≈øen≈øibility is, on the contrary, proportionably increa≈øed by reflection and attention. Now to ≈øay that tho≈øe
who live very much without moral reflection and attention; therefore cannot determine otherwi≈øe with them≈øelves, is implicitly to deny that they have the faculty of rea≈øon. They can deliberate on the means and opportunities of gratifying their lu≈øts. What good rea≈øon can be offer'd to ≈øhew they have not power to turn their meditations into another channel?

But as it is an important duty of moral agents to accu≈øtom them≈øelves to diligent enquiry and mature con≈øideration, that they may know what they ought to chu≈øe and pur≈øue, and what to refu≈øe and avoid, and not act as the hor≈øe and mule who have no under≈øtanding‚Äî≈øo it ≈øhou'd not be forgotten, that they ≈øometimes deliberate with a very different and oppo≈øite view‚Äînot to di≈øcover their duty where it is doubtful, but to explain it away where it is plain. In ca≈øes where an uprignt mind can be at no lo≈øs, but makes immediate choice, a di≈øhone≈øt heart will he≈øitate, and, under a notion of deliberating in order to di≈øcover what may or ought to be done, contriveth excu≈øes for the violation of a clear command. Sometimes great and ≈øcandalous vices are refined upon till they are tho't to be no vices; perhaps are transformed into virtues. In re≈øpect to things that are evident. Burlamaqui's principles of law, Vol. I. p. 17, 18; 24‚Äî27; 34, 35; 59, 60; 238; 248; 258. The remaining part of

He defines liberty thus: Liberty is power, opportunity or advantage that any one has to do as he plea≈øeth. If he is able, and there is nothing in the way to hinder his pur≈øuing and executing his will, the man is fully and perfectly free. Whence it is manife≈øt, that Mr. Edwards had no other notion of liberty than what re≈øpects external action or conduct. The plea≈øure of the mind, and acting or conducting according to it, are entirely different. And where natural nece≈ø≈øity doth not take place, it is conceded, that virtue or vice con≈øi≈øts not in the external doing or forbearing, but in the ≈øtate and di≈øpo≈øition of the mind or will. Mr. Edwards's rea≈øoning on this point, reduced to proper form, will ≈øtand thus: Liberty is e≈ø≈øential to prai≈øe or blame. Liberty con≈øi≈øts in a man's pur≈øuing and executing his will. Ergo, If he he cannot execute his will,

In truth, whether moral agents ≈øhall execute their wills depends not on them≈øelves. Their natural liberty may be abridged of taken away, and yet their freedom as accountable creatures remain. If then liberty be really nece≈ø≈øary to prai≈øe of blame, it mu≈øt con≈øi≈øt in a power either to chu≈øe or refu≈øe that wherein virtue and vice con≈øi≈øt. And con≈øequently the will it≈øelf, its ≈øtate, volitions or acts, mu≈øt be determined by moral agents them≈øelves‚Äîat lea≈øt in ≈øome in≈øtances, and within a certain mea≈øure. If he means any thing by the freedom of the ≈øoul as a moral agent, it is this, that moral agents are ≈øo framed, have ≈øuch di≈øpo≈øitions con-created with them, or infufed into them by the author of their beings, that they exerci≈øe freely what is created with or infu≈øed into them, and can do no otherwi≈øe. As ≈øuppo≈øe one hath a propen≈øity to intemperance; another to uncleanne≈øs, a third to theft, a fourth to covetou≈øne≈øs and extortion, a fifth to pride, malice or revenge, &c. in exerci≈øing, pur≈øuing or executing the≈øe different pa≈ø≈øions they are re≈øpectively free, they act as they plea≈øe, or according to their will; but have no hand in the formation of the≈øe various propen≈øities. So are the different ≈øpecies of animals, who pur≈øue and execute their peculiar propen≈øities‚Äîwho follow nature‚Äîthat is the in≈øtincts and di≈øpo≈øitions implanted in them by the author of nature. p.q: Our actions proceed from our wills, but our wills mu≈øt be derived from the natural di≈øpo≈øitions implanted in us by the author of our being: Wrong elections proceed from wrong apprehen≈øions, or unruly pa≈ø≈øions; and the≈øe from our original frame or accidental education. div.head: SECTION II. On the influence of motives in moral volitions.
div.p: THE near relation this part of our ≈øubject hath to the preceeding naturally leads us to ≈øuch ob≈øervations as may be explanatory of the things already offered, and ≈øtrengthen their evidence: While what hath been ≈øaid may an≈øwer the ≈øame purpo≈øe with re≈øpect to what we ≈øhall now offer on the relation motives have to the volitions of moral agents.

The whole di≈øpute turns on the deci≈øion of this que≈øtion, Whether moral agents have a principle of efficiency in them≈øelves? In what follows, we ≈øhall endeavor further to ≈øupport the affirmative.

By motives we mean external rea≈øons or inducements exhibited to the view of a moral agent. Mr. Edwards, in a more general way, intends (as we ≈øuppo≈øe) an extrin≈øic moral cau≈øe, by the term motive. We are very ≈øen≈øible he had no fixed meaning to this word in his writings. We took notice of his vague and arbitrary u≈øe and application of it, Examination ≈øect. 2. part I ‚Äîparticularly p. 26. marg. In the ≈øen≈øe he ≈øometimes u≈øeth the word [motive] it is not extrin≈øic to the mind, nor even antecedent to volition, nor di≈øtinct from it‚Äîcon≈øequently, hath not a tendency to excite volition, is not the cau≈øe, nor ≈øo much as the occa≈øion of it. To ≈øpeak of the preponderation and prevalency of motive implies that the mind is already determined; that its choice is made. And hence a preponderating, prevalent motive is not the determiner of the mind's election. The cau≈øe of this is ≈øtill to be ≈øought ≈øomewhere el≈øe. One while Mr. Edwards blends motive and volition‚Äîat another time he makes the former the moral cau≈øe of the latter‚Äîthen again intimates that motive is not a proper efficient, but only an occa≈øion of volition‚Äîthen turns about and blends perception and action.

He affirms motives to be moral cau≈øes, by way of di≈øtinction
from natural cau≈øes; and, according to his rea≈øoning, they produce their effects in the ≈øame way‚Äîthat is, through the divine energy. Moral effects nece≈ø≈øarily follow the efficiency of their cau≈øe‚Äîmoral cau≈øes are as ab≈øolute as natural. (P. 103; 261, &c.)

It might be abundantly ≈øhewn that Mr. Edwards a≈øcribes efficiency to motives, from his whole book; and more e≈øpecially from Part II. Sect. 10. But we ≈øhall only quote the following from p. 134, 135. in confirmation hereof. If motives excite volition, then they are the CAUSE of it's being excited‚ÄîTo excite, is po≈øitively to do ≈øomething; and certainly that which does ≈øomething, is the CAUSE of the thing done by it. To create, is to cau≈øe to be created; to make, is to cau≈øe to be made‚Äî to quicken, is to cau≈øe to be quickened; and to excite, is to cau≈øe to be excited. To excite, is to be a cau≈øe in the mo≈øt proper ≈øen≈øe, not meerly a negative occa≈øion, but a ground of exi≈øtence by po≈øitive influence. The notion of exciting, is exerting influence to cau≈øe the effect to ari≈øe or come forth into exi≈øtence‚ÄîThe production of an effect is certainly the cau≈øing of an effect; and productive influence is cau≈øal influence, if any thing is; and that which has this influence prevalently, ≈øo as thereby to become the ground of another thing, is a cau≈øe of that thing, if there be any ≈øuch thing as a cau≈øe. Tho≈øe who are ≈øtill di≈øpo≈øed to que≈øtion whether Mr. Edwards a≈øcribes cau≈øality or efficiency to motives may call to mind the ≈øtory he tells of the animal in Terra del Fuego. (p. 282.)

However, we ≈øee not what advantage can accrue to Mr. Edwards's ≈øcheme, or what injury to our own, ≈øhould it be granted, that upon his plan motives are not, in a ≈øtrict ≈øen≈øe, the cau≈øe of moral volitions. For if ≈øo, what was he about when he wrote his book? Was it not his declared de≈øign to point out the cau≈øe of volition? Doth he not labour abundantly to prove, that this cau≈øe mu≈øt evermore be that motive, which, in the view of the agent, is highe≈øt? If by this moral cau≈øe, as he ≈øpeaks, nothing more be meant than the occa≈øion of volition, not the cau≈øe in a ≈øtrict and proper ≈øen≈øe, how has he then an≈øwered the que≈øtion propo≈øed, viz. "What determines the will? To
≈øay that motive is the occa≈øion of the will's determination; is nothing to the purpo≈øe. We want to be directed to the efficient. This enquiry is of no le≈øs importance than it is to know the proper cau≈øe of every moral event. It Mr. Edwards did not ≈øuppo≈øe motives to be efficient cau≈øes, volition can have no ≈øuch cau≈øe at all on his ≈øcheme.‚ÄîIn other words, there could be no ≈øuch effect as a moral volition. For a moral effect cannot exi≈øt without a cau≈øe any more than a natural effect: And Mr. Edwards denieth that the ≈øubject of ≈øuch volition, can be the efficient or producer of it, So that to deny motives efficiency to produce volition, is, upon his principles, to ≈øay, that all moral events are without a cau≈øe‚Äîrather, that there are no ≈øuch events exi≈øting.

Should it be ≈øaid, that creatures to whom moral agency belongs are the proper efficients of their own volitions, this would be directly to admit our doctrine‚Äîto a≈ø≈øert a ≈øelf-determining power, and make this the foundation of prai≈øe and blame, rewards and puni≈øhments. Should it be ≈øaid that the fir≈øt cau≈øe is the proper efficient of every moral volition, this would rather increa≈øe than relieve the difficulty. For it equally militates with Mr. Edwards's ≈øcheme to ≈øuppo≈øe a ≈øelf-determining power in the creator, as in the creature. And then to a≈øcribe the ≈øinful volitions of creatures to divine efficiency, is to affirm that God is the proper cau≈øe and author of wickedne≈øs. In every view Mr. Edwards's ≈øcheme is ≈øtrangely embarra≈ø≈øed. It is conceded, that every moral volition hath an efficient cau≈øe. And is it a trivial point whether this cau≈øe be ≈øuppo≈øed to be in the ≈øubject of ≈øuch volition, or extrin≈øic to him?

As, on Mr. Edwards's principles, the efficient cau≈øe of the moral volitions of creatures mu≈øt be either extrin≈øic motive, or God him≈øelf through the intervention of motive, each of the≈øe ca≈øes ≈øhall be di≈øtinctly examined: And if neither of them can be maintained, the other opinion mu≈øt be the truth, that moral agents are the cau≈øe of their own volitions.

Now it cannot be that motives are them≈øelves efficient cau≈øes. For an efficient mu≈øt needs be an agent. A moral
efficient mu≈øt be a mu≈øt agent. Ab≈øtract notions (as all rea≈øons and motives are) are not agents. Or ≈øhould it be ≈øaid that moral agency belongs to them, it would no way ≈øerve Mr. Edward's cau≈øe. For if motives are agents, then they are them≈øelves determined by motive. To be an efficient is to act, and action implies agency. If motives are not agents, then either the ≈øubject of a moral volition is al≈øo the moral cau≈øe of it, or ≈øome other agent is that cau≈øe. To ≈øay ≈øome other agent is the cau≈øe, is either to a≈øcribe ≈øelf-determination to this ≈øuppo≈øed cau≈øe, or to run back the efficient of volition in infinitum.

Mr. Edwards him≈øelf ≈øaith, that the act of volition is determined always by that in the mind's view of an object, which cau≈øeth it to appear mo≈øt agreable, not by the agreable appearance it≈øelf; for this, in his opinion, is nothing di≈øtinct from volition (P. 11, 12.) This matter was particularly con≈øidered, Examination, part I. ≈øect. 2. To ≈øave the reader (and our≈øelves al≈øo) the trouble of repetition, we beg leave to refer moreover, to the notes p. 91,‚Äî95.

If motives are not them≈øelves efficients, let us next enquire, whether God is the efficient cau≈øe of all moral volitions in the creatures through the medium of motives. Now in a moral e≈øtimation, it makes no difference, whether the Deity be the immediate or mediate cau≈øe of ≈øin and moral turpitude. To ≈øay he is the efficient in either ≈øen≈øe is equally and infinitely reproachful to him. To ≈øay, the will nece≈ø≈øarily follows the la≈øt dictate of the under≈øtanding‚Äîthat the under≈øtanding follows the appearance of things
Objection: "It is not in our power to perceive things otherwi≈øe than as they offer them≈øelves to our mind; now our judgments are formed on this perception of things; and it is by the≈øe judgments that the will is determined: The whole is therefore nece≈ø≈øary and independent of liberty."
An≈øwer. "This difficulty carries little more with it than an empty appearance. Let people ≈øay what they will, we are always at liberty to open or ≈øhut our eyes to the light; to exert, or relax our attention. Experience ≈øhews, that when we view an object in different lights, and determine to ≈øearch into the bottom of matters, we de≈øery ≈øeveral things that e≈øcaped us at fir≈øt ≈øight. This it ≈øufficient to prove that there is an exerci≈øe of liberty in the operations of the under≈øtanding, as well as in the ≈øeveral actions thereon depending." Burlamaqui principles of laws, vol, 1, p. 19. and that the≈øe appearances are all minutely ordered
and di≈øpo≈øed by the governor of the world, is ultimately to a≈øcribe all moral evil to his efficiency. But how con≈øi≈øtently with his moral character? For can it be that the efficient cau≈øe of wickedne≈øs is not wicked?

Should it be admitted that motives may, in ≈øome ca≈øes, be exhibited in ≈øo ≈øtrong a light, that the mind in which they are extant could not but make the choice it doth; yet unle≈øs this can be ≈øhewn to hold true in every in≈øtance, the doctrine of nece≈ø≈øary determination cannot be ≈øupported. Admitting, for in≈øtance, this irre≈øi≈øtible exhibition of motives to take place, with reference to angels and glorified ≈øpirits in heaven, and in ≈øome ca≈øes of good men on

We have not pretended to ≈øtate the degree of moral liberty, or ≈øphere of its exerci≈øe by moral agents. Mr. Edwards repre≈øents tho≈øe writers who argue for a liberty of indifference, particularly Dr. Watts, as meaning hereby two contrary things, neither of which was their ≈øentiment. We might mention in≈øtances of the will's determination, in which there is no perceptible preference, either in the object it≈øelf fixed upon, or in the circum≈øtances of it. However, ≈øuch arbitriums ≈øeem not to belong to the ≈øubject of morality and religion. They ≈øtill ≈øubvert Mr. Edwards's ≈øcheme of nece≈ø≈øary connection.
"The exerci≈øe of liberty," ≈øays the learned Burlamaqui, never di≈øplays it≈øelf more than in indifferent things. As to the mind's giving it≈øelf up to accident, this ca≈øe is wrongly ≈øtated. Where the mind has a full per≈øua≈øion there is no preferablene≈øs of one ob≈øect to another, is in≈øtantly convinc'd they are exactly alike, it cannot be ≈øaid to give it≈øelf up to accident. Virtuous or vicious elections mu≈øt proceed upon motive. And we grant that the greate≈øt good really ought to determine moral agents; but that it in fact always doth, even where it is perceived, we deny. Where there is both a real and evident preferablene≈øs, there can be no di≈øpute as to the obligations of moral agents. Still we think nothing is more evidently fal≈øe than the opinion, that the affections evermore follow the la≈øt practical judgment of the under≈øtanding. But to confound all di≈øtinction between motives and moral habits, as Mr. Edwards doth, is to blend things that differ‚Äîto contradict rea≈øon and him≈øelf. For he tells us, volition follows perception, is excited by it, and the effect of it‚Äîthat motives are extrin≈øic cau≈øes. Surely then they are different from volition. And if (as has been ≈øhewn) volition is not always as the highe≈øt motive; then, when the≈øe really meet, it is not nece≈ø≈øarily; that is, not in the way Mr. Edwards contends for. One in≈øtance failing, the chain is broken. One link, or "10,000, breaks the chain alike."

Motives exhibited to a moral agent may be ≈øtrong or weak according to the attention given to them. Mo≈øt pre≈øumptuous ≈øins may proceed from ≈øudden pa≈ø≈øion or inattention. It has been hinted, that Adam's fir≈øt ≈øin may

On Mr. Edwards's ≈øcheme and our own, extrin≈øic motives are concerned, as they have po≈øitive influence, in moral volitions. To ≈øay that volition ≈øprings from it≈øelf, is a very different thing from ≈øaying, that the ≈øubject is the cau≈øe of it. Dr. Watts did not deny that volition hath a cau≈øe, as Mr. Edwards would in≈øinuate; but maintain'd, that an intelligent ≈øpirit is the cau≈øe of it's own volitions.

div.head: SECTION III. On nece≈ø≈øity.
div.p: TO make his doctrine of univer≈øal nece≈ø≈øity con≈øi≈øtent with moral agency and accountablene≈øs, Mr. Edwards in≈øi≈øts much on two kinds of nece≈ø≈øity; one of which he calls natural; the other, moral. It is needful to exhibit his doctrine, and make a few remarks thereon, that the reader may judge of the merits of this di≈øtinction. He frequently adverti≈øeth his readers, that when he applieth the term nece≈ø≈øity to moral ≈øubjects, he u≈øeth it "as a term of art"‚Äîthat when the words nece≈ø≈øary, impo≈ø≈øible, irre≈øi≈øtible, unable, &c. are applied to moral agency, they are either u≈øed in ≈øome new ≈øen≈øe diver≈øe from their original and proper meaning, or with perfect in≈øignificance and non≈øen≈øe: For no inability what≈øoever, which is meerly moral, is properly called by the name of inability. (P. 21, 22, 232, 287. et pa≈ø≈øim.) Did not Mr. Edwards then mean by moral nece≈ø≈øity any real nece≈ø≈øity? Did he u≈øe words as "non≈øen≈øically" as other metaphy≈øicians?

While in common ≈øpeech no proper nece≈ø≈øity at all is meant by the u≈øe of the terms moral nece≈ø≈øity, When in common ≈øpeech it is ≈øaid, that any particular things are morally nece≈ø≈øary, or morally impo≈ø≈øible, by way of di≈øtinction from natural nece≈ø≈øity or impo≈ø≈øibility, nothing more is intended than to expre≈øs, on the one hand, the degree of probability, or at mo≈øt moral certainty, that ≈øuch events will take place: Or, on the other hand, the difficulty that is in the way, and the moral evidence that they will not become effect. When we ≈øay, We mu≈øt do or forbear ≈øuch things‚Äîwe cannot but do or forbear them‚Äîwe are nece≈ø≈øitated to do or forbear them, we would only expre≈øs the ≈øtrength of obligation upon us, or the ≈øtrong inducements we are under, in our pre≈øent ≈øituation and circum≈øtances, to do or omit them, When we ≈øay of a man of approved veracity and fidelity, that he cannot lie, or violate his tru≈øt and engagements, we mean that we have moral certainty he will ≈øpeak the truth, and be faithful to his promi≈øes, to the tru≈øt repo≈øed in him‚Äîthat we have the highe≈øt rea≈øon to think ≈øo, and no ≈øu≈øpicion to the contrary; Not ≈øuppo≈øing but it may be barely po≈ø≈øible, however improbable, that he may prove fal≈øe and unfaithful. (For ≈øuch men ≈øometimes act unworthy of their general character, to the great ≈øurprize of their acquaintance.) When it is ≈øaid of tho≈øe who have been long accu≈øtomed to do evil, that they cannot learn to do well, by this is only ≈øignified the extreme difficulty of their reforming; the great improbability of it. We ≈øometimes ≈øay, it is next to impo≈ø≈øible ≈øuch ≈øhould be reclaimed, and find their recovery in ≈øcripture re≈øembled to a natural impo≈ø≈øibility. (Jer. XIII. 23.) The meaning is not, that there is any ≈øtrict nece≈ø≈øity of their per≈øi≈øting in ≈øin. There have been in≈øtances of ≈øuch per≈øons reclaimed, and there may be again, great as their danger is. Therefore we cannot ≈øay, 'tis ab≈øolutely certain others of this character will never be reduced; much le≈øs that there is an ab≈øolute nece≈ø≈øity of their continuing unreformed. The ≈øeveral in≈øtances produced by Mr. Edwards (P. 34.) will all apply again≈øt him≈øelf. manife≈øtly intends hereby a real nece≈ø≈øity, and in his definition of moral nece≈ø≈øity includes what properly belongs to natural‚Äîapplying to it the following epithets, infallible, unalterable, unfru≈øtrable, unavoidable‚Äîand ≈øaying (P. 30.) "By natural nece≈ø≈øity, as applied to men, I mean," ≈øaith he, ≈øuch nece≈ø≈øity as men are under through the force of natural cau≈øes; as di≈øtingui≈øhed from what are called moral cau≈øes, ≈øuch as habits and di≈øpo≈øitions of the heart, and moral motives and inducements. By moral nece≈ø≈øity is meant that nece≈ø≈øity of connection and con≈øequence, which ari≈øeth from the ≈øtrength of ≈øuch moral cau≈øes as the ≈øtrength of inclination, or motives, and the connection which there is in many ca≈øes between the≈øe, and ≈øuch certain volitions and actions. (P. 29.) To prevent any mi≈øtake of his meaning, he gives us notice of the≈øe three things. Fir≈øt, that moral nece≈ø≈øity may be as ab≈øolute

div.head: SECTION IV. On the origin of evil.
div.p: MR. Edwards's opinion on this ≈øubject is, that ≈øin infallibly followed from God's ordering man's circum≈øtances when he made him, and withholding or withdrawing divine influence and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance. Fir≈øt, He contradicts him≈øelf. We ≈øhall take notice only of two re≈øpects in which he doth ≈øo. His own illu≈øtration of the ≈øubject goes upon the ≈øuppo≈øition,

2. Admit the exi≈øtence of ≈øin to be the con≈øequence, not of any po≈øitive influence of the deity, but to follow only from his forbearing to influence and a≈ø≈øi≈øt the creature, in like manner as darkne≈øs and fro≈øt in the night follow upon the departure of the ≈øun‚Äîadmit that God is not the efficient cau≈øe of ≈øin; it will then follow, that the ≈øinful being him≈øelf mu≈øt be this cau≈øe. Now to ≈øay that the perpetrator of wickedne≈øs is the efficient cau≈øe of it, is to e≈øtabli≈øh a power of ≈øelf-determination, contrary to the principal de≈øign of Mr. Edwards's book. Secondly, His doctrine is repugnant to the fundamental and mo≈øt important principles of rea≈øon and religion. It is a≈øcribing ≈øin as really, and in as obnoxious a ≈øen≈øe, to God, as to affirm, his po≈øitive agency and efficiency herein. Mr. Edwards would have been more con≈øi≈øtent with him≈øelf, had he embraced the latter opinion. His ≈øcheme can hang together on no other ≈øuppo≈øition. But his doctrine re≈øpecting the manner of ≈øin's coming into exi≈øtence ≈øhall be examined ≈øomewhat di≈øtinctly.

If ≈øin aro≈øe from God's withdrawing his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance and influence, it will then follow that the creature had originally ≈øuch influence and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance as was ≈øufficient to prevent apo≈øtacy. For ≈øuppo≈øe the creature never had ≈øufficient divine influence and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance to ≈øecure his primitive rectitude, his ≈øtate would have been analogous to primitive darkne≈øs and eternal night. If therefore there is any pertinency in the in≈øtance Mr.

Again, we might much more con≈øi≈øtently ≈øuppo≈øe, that God would have put an end to the exi≈øtence of a rational creature, than have continued ≈øuch an one in being and withdrawn his influence, previous to any direct forfeiture on the creatures part. This doctrine gives us ≈øuch an idea of the parent of the univer≈øe as ≈øhocks the fir≈øt principles of rea≈øon, and contradicts the cleare≈øt notices God has given of him≈øelf by the light of nature and ≈øcripture. Moral agents are the off≈øpring

Surely there is a difference, and one of great importance, in the≈øe ca≈øes. We mean not to ≈øet forth this doctrine in colours more ≈øhocking to the imagination, and moving to the pa≈ø≈øions, than it de≈øerves. 'Tis impo≈ø≈øible. That to a≈øcribe the origin of evil to the want of divine influence and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance is not materially different from a≈øcribing it to the po≈øitive energy and efficiency of God. His own immediate conduct is original in the ≈øeries, either his acting, or forbearing to act. Mr. Edwards ≈øaith indeed, "God don't will ≈øin as ≈øin." It is above our comprehen≈øion, that the Deity ≈øhould will, order and determine that action in the creature, which cannot be done without ≈øin, and not at the ≈øame time will the ≈øin of it‚Äîas ≈øuppo≈øe theft, adultery, murder, bla≈øphemy. But how is this reconcileable with that deci≈øive determining providence re≈øpecting every event, which Mr. Edwards undertakes to defend? On the≈øe things we ob≈øerve, that divine communications were as nece≈ø≈øary to pre≈øerve innocent beings in a ≈øtate of rectitude, as they are to ≈øupport and perfect the ≈øpiritual life in the regenerate, who are kept by the power of God. For the creature might as well continue to live, after God taketh away his breath, as continue holy after the withdraw of divine influence. The repre≈øentation Mr. Edwards's ≈øcheme gives us of the wi≈øe and good governor of the univer≈øe is ≈øummarily this, By the ≈øu≈øpen≈øion of divine influence, beings made holy become unholy, no longer capable of holy exerci≈øes‚Äîevery imagination of their hearts only evil continually‚Äîdead in ≈øin‚Äîobnoxious to all the di≈ømal effects of God's wrath in this world and that to come‚Äîand an innumerable

No rea≈øon can, indeed, be given why divine influence & a≈ø≈øi≈øtance ≈øhould be withdrawn from men and angels antecedent to their fall, which would not equally ju≈øtify the governor of the world had he never imparted ≈øuch influence and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance to them. To ≈øay that their defection aro≈øe from the imperfection which properly belongs to a creature, as ≈øuch, wou'd not at all relieve the difficulty. When Mr. Edwards ≈øaith, that "≈øin aro≈øe from the imperfection which properly belongs to creature, as ≈øuch; we ≈øuppo≈øe he means the ≈øame as when he ≈øaith it aro≈øe from the want or withholding of divine influence and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance. It was contrary to his nature and bias con≈øidered as endowed with the ≈øpiritual and moral image of God. Angels and men were made perfect in their order, as creatures, however capable of improvement, both intellectual and moral. They were, in this ≈øen≈øe, perfect, till iniquity was found in them. On the whole, his doctrine, while it acquits the creature from all blame, impeacheth the Creator as the po≈øitive cau≈øe and ≈øource of the revolt of angels and mankind, and ultimately fixeth all the criminality in the univer≈øe on him. natural‚Äîthat with regard to God, vice is the con≈øequence of mi≈øery‚Äîthat God is, and mu≈øt be, the author of ≈øin, as the contrary would be to ≈øay, that ≈øomething exi≈øts without any cau≈øe at all‚Äî that he is the author of all natural evil, and in the ≈øame manner, on the ≈øame principle, the author of all moral evil‚Äîthat he made creatures with morally evil di≈øpo≈øitions Ibid. p. 11; 100,‚Äî109.‚ÄîThis ≈øcheme, the author affirms, is the only one, on which the doctrines of original ≈øin, prede≈øtination and redemption can be vindicated‚Äîthat Chri≈øtianity can be defended on no other plan. div.head: SECTION V. On the connection between the nature and cau≈øe of volition.
div.p: IT is a favourite di≈øtinction with Mr. Edwards, that the e≈ø≈øence of vertue and vice lies in the nature of volition, not in the cau≈øe. We before took ≈øome ≈ølight notice of the futility of this di≈øtinction. We knew, indeed, that the con≈øi≈øtency of Mr. Edwards's ≈øcheme depended not a little on the propriety of di≈øtingui≈øhing the nature of moral actions from their cau≈øe: But had we repre≈øented ≈øuch a di≈øtinction as really important, upon his plan, po≈ø≈øibly it might have been e≈øteem'd invidious. However, we are now con≈øtrained to ≈øay, ≈øuch a repre≈øentation wou'd have been the exact truth. And though we ≈øtill think the di≈øtinction futile and eva≈øive, yet we have a rea≈øon, which we had not when we wrote before, for giving this matter a particular con≈øideration. Our having been publickly called upon (not in very obliging terms E≈ø≈øay on moral agency, part I. ≈øect. 4.) to point out the weakne≈øs of this di≈øtinction, will excu≈øe us with the reader, ≈øhou'd he think more notice is now taken of it, than it really de≈øerves.
We ≈øhall fir≈øt examine the merits of this di≈øtinction‚Äî and then remind the reader of the importance of it on Mr. Edwards's plan.

Fir≈øt, Of the merits of it. To ≈øay the e≈ø≈øence of virtue and vice lies in their nature, is only ≈øaying, that the nature of them con≈øi≈øts in their nature. Or the propo≈øition might be tran≈øpo≈øed thus: The nature of virtue and vice lies in their e≈ø≈øence. The word nature needs explaining as much as the word e≈ø≈øence. To u≈øe the former as a definition or explanation of the latter, wou'd not be le≈øs trifling than to attempt to explain the term nece≈ø≈øary, by the words mu≈øt, can, cannot, of which Mr. Edwards takes notice. (P. 18.) We don't advance one ≈øtep in our under≈øtanding of the ≈øubject by ≈øuch explanations. Shou'd any one a≈øk, wherein doth the e≈ø≈øence of virtue and vice con≈øi≈øt? and receive
for an≈øwer, It con≈øi≈øts in it's nature‚Äîwou'd he think the an≈øwer le≈øs impertinent, or be le≈øs di≈øpo≈øed to laugh at him that offers it, than if upon a≈øking an explanation of the word nece≈ø≈øity, he ≈øhou'd be an≈øwered, that which is nece≈ø≈øary, mu≈øt and cannot but be?

We de≈øire no logical proof that the nature of virtue and vice lie in the nature of a virtuous or vicious di≈øpo≈øition. We allow that ≈øuch a di≈øpo≈øition is what it is; and think there was no occa≈øion to fill the page with proofs of this ≈øort. For who is fool enough to di≈øpute the thing! But doth this ≈øhow us what con≈øtitutes the nature of virtue and vice? what it is that makes any particular action or di≈øpo≈øition virtuous or vicious? Or doth it follow, from admitting that the nature of vertue and vice lies in their nature, that therefore their nature is ≈øeperable from their cau≈øe? or that one can be judged of detach'd from the other? Were vertue and vice, as effects in the natural world, produc'd by the efficiency of ≈øome cau≈øe extrin≈øic to the ≈øubject, and in which he is but a pa≈ø≈øive recipient, then, indeed, we might detach their cau≈øe from their nature. But this is beging the que≈øtion. It ≈øtill remains to be proved, that vertue and vice in rational agents are the production of a cau≈øe extrin≈øic to them≈øelves.

This di≈øtinction of Mr. Edwards's is, therefore, ≈øubtil and eva≈øive, as it carries in it an intimation, that his opponents deny the e≈ø≈øence of volition to lie in it's nature, and maintain it lies in it's cau≈øe by way of di≈øtinction from it's nature. div.p: "I BELIEVE," ≈øaith Mr. Edwards, there is no per≈øon of good under≈øtanding, who will venture to ≈øay, he is certain that it is impo≈ø≈øible it ≈øhould be be≈øt‚Äî that there ≈øhould be ≈øuch a thing as moral evil in the world. Mr. Edwards, it will be remembered, proceeds upon this ≈øuppo≈øition, that the infinite creator, before the world was, having in contemplation all po≈ø≈øible ≈øy≈øtems, gave the preference to one including moral evil, as be≈øt calculated to manife≈øt his perfections. Hence he affirms it to be

Or thus much at lea≈øt we ≈øuppo≈øe will follow from the things that have been ob≈øerved, that the advantage of moral evil to the world is not proveable in the way Mr. Edwards has attempted to prove it‚Äîthe re≈øult of which is, that God may do evil, that good may come. div.head: SECTION VII. On Foreknowledge.

q.l: Others apart ≈øat on a hill retired,

div.p: NO que≈øtion on the ≈øubject of morals hath more perplexed the learned than this, How is divine pre≈øcience reconcileable with liberty in the creature? While mo≈øt (and among the≈øe the wi≈øe≈øt of men) have mode≈øtly confe≈ø≈øed their ignorance, and looked upon the que≈øtion as unan≈øwerable by an human under≈øtanding; ≈øome few have attempted to ≈øolve the difficulty. But the attempt hath been executed in ≈øuch a manner as hath rather evidenced the folly and arrogance of the undertakers, than cleared the ≈øubject. The reader will hence conclude, that the ≈øolution of this difficulty is not what we propo≈øe in the pre≈øent ≈øection.

But ≈øince ≈øome gentlemen ≈øeem to ≈øuppo≈øe, that pre≈øcience and liberty cannot both be firmly believed unle≈øs the mind of man can reconcile them‚Äî≈øince Mr. Edwards ≈øeems to think his own ≈øcheme altogether clear of this difficulty; and ≈øince from the divine pre≈øcience he infers his doctrine of nece≈ø≈øity; the≈øe things ≈øhall be briefly examined in this place.

To ≈øay that pre≈øcience and liberty are ab≈øolutely irreconcileable, becau≈øe we our≈øelves cannot reconcile them, would be to take the dimen≈øions of the divine mind from our own. An infinite under≈øtanding may be able to reconcile them, when a finite cannot. If any ≈øubject involves difficulties, which we cannot ≈øolve, we may not immediately infer a contradiction in it. For what ≈øubject can be mentioned that doth not involve ≈øuch difficulties? If we determine to believe no doctrines, till we ≈øee how the≈øe things can be, this will land us in ab≈øolute ≈øceptici≈øm.
Do we believe nothing but what we can give a rationale of? 'Tis manife≈øt then, that we do not believe the divine exi≈øtence, nor that of any other beings or things‚Äî not even our own exi≈øtence. For who pretends to know after what manner God exi≈øts? or to be acquainted with the e≈ø≈øences of other things? The divine eternity, infinity, omni≈øcience, &c. tran≈øcend all our conceptions. We are wholly ignorant how our own ≈øouls and bodies are united‚Äî are lo≈øt in the contemplation of our own frame. The trinity and ≈øatisfaction are inexplicable my≈øteries. The ≈øcheme of Chri≈øtianity, and the whole moral government of God, are incomprehen≈øible. Nor would they be otherwi≈øe, and be worthy of him who is perfect in knowledge. His judgments are un≈øearchable, and his ways pa≈øt finding out. As the heavens are higher than the earth, ≈øo are his thoughts and ways above ours. Although we have ≈øuch evidence in general of the truth and reality of the things above-mentioned as in a manner compels our belief; yet when the que≈øtion is put, How can the≈øe things be? we di≈øcern in≈øuperable difficulties‚Äîat the ≈øame time we are con≈øcious infidelity would involve us in difficulties ≈øtill greater.

With re≈øpect to the que≈øtion before us, if the voice of ≈øcripture or rea≈øon be hearkned to, we mu≈øt admit both pre≈øcience and liberty‚Äîand that they are con≈øi≈øtent, tho' after a manner inconceivable by us. For we cannot believe evident contradictions.

We u≈øe the term foreknowledge in accommodation to our own narrow views and way of conceiving things. In an infinite under≈øtanding, there is no before or after‚Äî no ≈øucce≈ø≈øion of ideas. To him who calleth things that are not as though they were, and with whom a thou≈øand years are as one day, the knowledge of futurity is pre≈øent, knowledge. How then can a finite mind conceive the manner of his knowing futurity? Is there any thing in vi≈øible creation that affords a re≈øemblance of what we call pre≈øcience. When we undertake to ≈øpeak on a ≈øubject ≈øo high and too wonderful for us, it becomes us to be diffident of our≈øelves, and very ≈øparing of words, remembering that we are of ye≈øterday‚ÄîTho≈øe ≈øeem not aware of
their own ignorance, and the danger of ≈øpeaking of God the thing that is not right, who attempt to explain this matter; as though by ≈øearching they could find out God ‚Äîas though he had taken coun≈øel with them. Ha≈øt thou heard the ≈øecret of God? And do≈øt thou re≈øtrain wi≈ødom to thy≈øelf?

Some men are apt to depart from evident truth out of regard to ab≈øtru≈øe ≈øpeculations. They turn a≈øide from the plain road of common ≈øen≈øe, di≈ødaining a beaten track, and are carried away with the error of the wicked, under pretence of new and important di≈øcoveries. If any truth be plain, this is, that man is free. Next to the con≈øciou≈øne≈øs of our own exi≈øtence is that of our moral freedom. Yet a truth ≈øo obvious is called in que≈øtion by ≈øome men, becau≈øe they cannot make it agree with the idea they have formed of God's infinite knowledge and eternal coun≈øels.

p.q:
As to the manner of God's foreknowing certainly contingent future events, that is, which have no nece≈ø≈øary cau≈øe, nor are to be accompli≈øhed by his own power, and the determination of his will, but produc'd by other free agents; this ≈øeems to be incomprehen≈øible by the human under≈øtanding. That any mind ≈øhould fore≈øee with certainty a di≈øtant event, which does not nece≈ø≈øarily proceed from the nature of things, nor is fix'd by the purpo≈øe of a voluntary agent, is wonderful to us and far ≈øurpa≈ø≈øeth our conception. For as our knowledge of futurity can only re≈øt on one or other of the≈øe foundations, we can form no di≈øtinct notion of any foreknowledge without them. It is probably their apprehending the divine pre≈øcience after the ≈øame manner, and limiting it to the ≈øame grounds, which has occa≈øioned ≈øo much perplexity in the minds of men, and involved their ≈øpeculations upon this ≈øubject in ≈øo much confu≈øion. Some imagining that contingent events could not otherwi≈øe be ≈øo a≈øcertained, as to be infallibly known, have ≈øuppo≈øed peremptory eternal decrees concerning all of them, even the free≈øt actions of men; and not only ≈øo, but a previous divine influence on the active powers of rational creatures, exciting them to action: But others judging this to be utterly incon≈øi≈øtent with human liberty,
and, with re≈øpect to evil actions, incon≈øi≈øtent with the purity and goodne≈øs of the divine nature, yet ≈øtill adhering to the ≈øame limited foundation of foreknowledge, have denied the doctrine of pre≈øcience altogether, or doubted concerning it. I believe the be≈øt way for us to get rid of the≈øe difficulties is wholly to neglect the hypothe≈øes, which have been invented to account for the manner of the divine pre≈øcience, acknowledging that it is to us inexplicable, and yet concluding that this is no ≈øufficient objection again≈øt a doctrine, otherwi≈øe well confirmed.

div.p: "I admire," ≈øays Dr. Eliot, the mode≈øty, as well as goodne≈øs of heart, di≈øcovered by the great Mr. Locke, in one of his letters to Mr. Molineux; "I freely own," ≈øays he, "the weakne≈øs of my under≈øtanding, that though it be unque≈øtionable, that there is omnipotence and omni≈øcience in God our maker, and I cannot have a clearer perception of any thing than that I am free; yet I cannot make freedom in man con≈øi≈øtent with omnipotence and omni≈øcience in God, though I am as fully per≈øuaded of both as of any truths I mo≈øt firmly a≈ø≈øent to, and therefore I have long ≈øince left off the con≈øideration of the que≈øtion. The Doctor ≈øubjoins to the≈øe words of Mr. Locke the following pertinent and ≈øea≈øonable reflection: If ≈øome of our modern rea≈øoners, who have not a tenth part of his under≈øtanding, had a little more of his humility, the world would be free from tho≈øe angry di≈øputes about fate and free-will, liberty and nece≈ø≈øity, which puzzle the heads, but ≈øeldom mend the hearts, of tho≈øe who engage in them. Dr Eliot's ≈øermon on natural religion, p, 21, 22.

To proceed: Pre≈øcience is a difficulty that encumbers Mr. Edwards's own ≈øcheme no le≈øs than that of his opponents. For he ≈øaith, There mu≈øt be a certainty in things them≈øelves before they are certainly foreknown, and affirms that the former "is the foundation" of the latter. (P. 22; 175.) Events have a fixed certain futurity prior to foreknowledge, and this antecedent nece≈ø≈øity of their coming to pa≈øs is the cau≈øe of their being certainly foreknown. What is meant by the certainty in things
them≈øelves prior to their exi≈øtence, is as unintelligible as his opinion, that there is in the nature of things a foundation for the knowledge of the being of God, without any evidence of it from his works; of which notice was taken, Examination, p. 36. marg. If by this certainty be meant any thing different from the divine decrees and determinations, then his argument will ≈øtand thus: The certainty there is in things them≈øelves is the foundation of the divine decrees; the divine decrees are the foundation of foreknowledge; and foreknowledge is the foundation of that nece≈ø≈øity which belongs to all events in the natural and moral world. This ≈øeems to be arguing in a circle. On the other hand, if by this certainty in things them≈øelves be meant the ≈øame as the divine decrees and determinations, then the≈øe being the ≈øuppo≈øed foundation of foreknowledge, the latter cannot be the cau≈øe of events, as Mr. Edwards repre≈øents, but the former. Nece≈ø≈øity is the cau≈øe of the knowledge of events, and not the knowledge of them the cau≈øe of their nece≈ø≈øity.

Further, If the purpo≈øes and decrees of God, or his determinations as to futurity, be antecedent to foreknowledge, and the foundation thereof, then his will is determined "at random, by blind contingence," without de≈øign or fore≈øight‚Äîguided by no wi≈ødom, no motive, no intelligent dictate whatever‚Äîhe only acts by an Hobbi≈øtical fatality. (P. 330, 334.) To ≈øpeak of the divine will as determined prior to knowledge, is plainly to ≈øuppo≈øe it determined without coun≈øel and wi≈ødom, undirected by knowledge and intelligence. And what holine≈øs can there be in ≈øuch determinations? It was ≈øurely through want of "reflection and re≈øearch"‚Äîthrough inattention to his own ≈øcheme, that Mr. Edwards grounds the certainty of foreknowledge on an antecedent nece≈ø≈øity of events ari≈øing from the divine coun≈øels and purpo≈øes. He repre≈øents the opinion of tho≈øe who teach that God's foreknowledge is antecedent to his decrees, as a ≈øervile ≈øubjecting the Deity to fatal nece≈ø≈øity; and ≈øaith, it argues inferiority and ≈øervitude unworthy of him, and comports with the heathen notion of fate as above the gods; becau≈øe this is to ≈øuppo≈øe, ≈øaith he, that events have a fixed certain futurity, to
which the divine volitions and de≈øigns are ≈øubject, and mu≈øt be accommodated. (p. 352, 353.) 'Tis not a little ≈øurprizing, that Mr. Edwards did not perceive this objection was much more applicable to his own doctrine, than to that of his oppo≈øers. Be≈øides, How do the≈øe things agree with his own words, p. 325. We mu≈øt conceive of the perfection of the divine under≈øtanding as the foundation of his wi≈øe purpo≈øes and decrees. As he is not herein reconcileable with him≈øelf, ≈øo his principles are not con≈øi≈øtent with the admi≈ø≈øion of forkenowledge. To ≈øay, the certainty of things, or divine determination of events, is antecedent to his perfect knowledge of futurity, is to deny pre≈øcience, and only to a≈øcribe after-knowledge to God. So that while Mr. Edwards ≈øuppo≈øeth his own ≈øcheme of nece≈ø≈øity clear of all difficulty from the head of fore-knowledge, it appears not only to militate with it≈øelf, but utterly to preclude that pre≈øcience from which he infers the nece≈ø≈øity of all events.

We will now enquire, in the la≈øt place, whether pre≈øcience implies nece≈ø≈øity. Mr. Edwards u≈øeth the terms certainty and nece≈ø≈øity, as tho' they were perfectly ≈øynonymous; and ≈øaith, Philo≈øophical nece≈ø≈øity is nothing different from certainty. (P. 22.) It is granted by all who believe fore-knowledge, that this really implies the certainty of all future events‚Äînot only that they will come to pa≈øs, but al≈øo that they will come to pa≈øs in ≈øuch a certain manner. But the inference is not, that they will come to pa≈øs nece≈ø≈øarily becau≈øe fore-known‚Äîthat they are indi≈ø≈øolubly connected as effects with pre≈øcience as their cau≈øe. Now it is in this ≈øen≈øe that Mr. Edwards maintains nece≈ø≈øity. If fore-knowledge infers nece≈ø≈øity (in his ≈øen≈øe of the word nece≈ø≈øity) then it implies an irre≈øi≈øtible determination of the wills and actions of moral agents.

Pre≈øcience has no cau≈øality in the coming to pa≈øs of the≈øe things which are the objects of it. So far is it from having any efficiency to produce them, that it hath no influence to their production by way of motive or excitement. For a motive is ≈øomething extant in the mind's view. Now can any moral agent know, previous to any given volition or action, that he ≈øhall certainly be determined to ≈øuch volition
or action? If not, then he cannot know that ≈øuch volition or action is certainly foreknown. For this would be to ≈øay, that what may never become effect may be foreknown. And if moral agents cannot tell beforehand what is foreknown with re≈øpect to them≈øelves, then foreknowledge can have no influence in determining their actions. For what is not perceived cannot excite or move to action; or determine the wills of moral agents; nor con≈øequently be con≈øidered as the cau≈øe, ground, or rea≈øon of their being determined to this or that. "Nothing," ≈øays Mr. Edwards, can induce or invite the mind to will or act any thing, any further than it is perceived, or is ≈øome way or other in the mind's view. (p. 8.) To ≈øay that pre≈øcience is in the view of the creature's mind, wou'd be to a≈øcribe an incommunicable attribute of the Creator to a creature. Foreknowledge, then, has no influence in bringing any moral volitions to pa≈øs‚Äînor is it even an occa≈øion of their becoming effect. It doth not ≈øtand in the relation of a cau≈øe, motive, rea≈øon or occa≈øion to the exi≈øtence of things to come, any more than our knowledge of things pa≈øt or pre≈øent has ≈øuch relation to their exi≈øtence. Herein we have Mr. Edwards's concurrence, p. 175. I freely allow that foreknowledge don't prove a thing to be nece≈ø≈øary, any more than after knowledge. Now doth our knowing that a thing is already come to pa≈øs imply that it came to pa≈øs nece≈ø≈øarily? If not, then neither doth foreknowledge of a future event imply that ≈øuch event mu≈øt come to pa≈øs by nece≈ø≈øity. That we know certainly an event hath already taken place, doth not imply that the nature of that event, or the manner of it's coming to pa≈øs, are determined by our knowledge. No more doth divine pre≈øcience affect the nature of events, or the manner of their coming into exi≈øtence.

Mr. Edwards, as hath been ob≈øerved, makes the divine determination, and deci≈øive ordering and di≈øpo≈øing of all events, the ground of their being foreknown‚Äîhe ≈øuppo≈øeth the divine determinations alike concern'd in moral volitions and actions, as in tho≈øe things which are the mere work of God‚Äîthat it properly belongs to him to di≈øpo≈øe, fix and determine the wills of all moral agents,
in every act, from the beginning of their exi≈øtence. And though he a≈ø≈øerts not in words a po≈øitive agency of God in evil actions; yet the thing in effect is a≈ø≈øerted, as hath been ≈øhewn. Section IV. Upon his ≈øcheme God is the author and cau≈øe of ≈øin; no le≈øs than of natural good and evil‚Äîthe author and cau≈øe of men's vices, no le≈øs than the giver and upholder of life, and fountain of their natural endowments and external advantages and enjoyments‚Äîthe author of evil di≈øpo≈øitions, no le≈øs than of holy and virtuous ones. But do not rea≈øon and ≈øcripture ≈øhew us, that there is an important difference between his being the author of the former and his being ≈øo of the latter‚Äî? that his operation, his determining and di≈øpo≈øing providence, cannot extend to moral evil? Every good gift, and every perfect gift, is from above, and cometh down from the father of lights. But God cannot be tempted with [moral] evil, neither tempteth he any man. James 1.13; 17. compared. All natural good and evil proceed from God as the proper cau≈øe. I, even I am he, and there is no god with me: I kill, and I make alive: I wound, and I heal. Neither is there any that can deliver out of my hand. (Deut. 32.39.) If it be a≈øk'd, how can natural evil, any more than moral, proceed from a good cau≈øe? the u≈øual an≈øwer is ≈øufficient, that the former is the penal con≈øequence of the latter. The difference between God's being the author of natural evil and of moral‚Äîbetween his being the fountain of holine≈øs and of ≈øin, is ≈øo obvious and important, and ≈øo clearly marked in ≈øcripture, that 'tis difficult to ≈øee how any man can excu≈øe him≈øelf in confounding the≈øe things. The effects of nece≈ø≈øary cau≈øes are, properly ≈øpeaking. God's own works. And rational creatures have an ab≈øolute dependance on him; all their powers are derived from him, and ≈øupported wholly by his providence. Yet it by no means follows, that the determination of their wills to vice is to be imputed to him as the cau≈øe that they are not them≈øelves the determiners of their own evil editions and actions. Doth foreknowledge infer ≈øuch nece≈ø≈øity? We need not ≈øcruple to ≈øay that the certainty of events, which foreknowledge implies is as diver≈øe from Mr. Edwards's philo≈øophic nece≈ø≈øity as truth is from fal≈øhood, or light from darkne≈øs. To ≈øupport his inference from foreknowledge, it was incumbent on him to ≈øhew, that this is an extrin≈øic efficient cau≈øe, who≈øe influence and operation brings into effect the things foreknown. To ≈øay, that foreknowledge is an antecedent, and the things foreknown con≈øequents, is but trifling, unle≈øs it can be ≈øhewn that the latter are indi≈ø≈øolubly connected with the former as the cau≈øe of their exi≈øtence. Mr. Edwards may
claim the honour of being the only author that attributes cau≈øation to foreknowledge.

"Foreknowledge," ≈øaith an excellent writer, has no influence at all upon the nature of things, to make the lea≈øt alteration in them. The events which are nece≈ø≈øary are foreknown as nece≈ø≈øary, and tho≈øe which are contingent and voluntary, are foreknown no otherwi≈øe than as contingent and voluntary.‚ÄîThe futurity of contingent events is real, though we cannot tell the cau≈øe of it, or upon what grounds it is to be known. A free action now done, was ye≈øterday, or in any preceeding point of duration, as truly future, as it has to day actually come to pa≈øs; therefore it is not impo≈ø≈øible (for our minds can di≈øcern no contradiction in it) that an infinite under≈øtanding ≈øhould foreknow ≈øuch events, though that knowledge is too high for us, or perhaps any finite mind, we cannot attain to it. And here we may ≈øafely re≈øt, as we find our≈øelves obliged to do in our enquiries concerning the other perfections of God, which are evidently proved to belong to his nature, and therefore believed, though to us incomprehen≈øible.‚ÄîWe cannot indeed believe contradictions, and to impo≈øe them upon us is to affront the rational nature; but it is no ab≈øurdity to believe the exi≈øtence and properties of a being, whom we cannot by ≈øearching find out, nor under≈øtand to perfection.
Abernethy's di≈øcour≈øe on divine omni≈øcience.

To ≈øupport his peculiar notion of divine foreknowledge and decrees, Mr. Edwards denies moral agents all liberty except what is merely external, and the re≈øult of nece≈ø≈øity in the mind. What pity is it that men, otherwi≈øe di≈øcerning, are tenacious of favorite hypothe≈øes, tho' mo≈øt ab≈øurd and prejudicial in their con≈øequences! If intelligent creatures are not free in a ≈øen≈øe different from the inferior animals, they cannot be ≈øaid to be moral agents‚Äîthe accountable authors of the things done by them: What they do mu≈øt, in a moral e≈øtimate, be con≈øidered as the action of ≈øome other being. There mu≈øt be ≈øelf-determination, or freedom, ≈øomewhere, in ≈øome one being at lea≈øt. And is it not very bold to a≈ø≈øert, that God is the producer of all the
wickedne≈øs in the world, by his agency? He that maintains this principle, that all our volitions and actions are nece≈ø≈øary, would ≈øoon be convinced of his folly were he to reduce the principle to practice. For mankind will think he is free‚Äîthat his actions are his own‚Äîand will treat him accordingly. He mu≈øt ≈øoon become intolerable to ≈øociety; and from the reception he meets with, he may clearly infer, that his fellow-creatures univer≈øally look upon him as a moral agent, and ≈øuppo≈øe he might have acted otherwi≈øe. And he mu≈øt be a ≈øtrange creature indeed, if, finding the opinion of nece≈ø≈øity in the moral actions of men (when reduced to practice) di≈øavowed, with one voice, by mankind, it doth not create in him ≈øome ≈øu≈øpicion wherether it be true, ≈øpeculatively con≈øidered.

p.q: It is a conclu≈øive argument again≈øt ≈øuch a fatal nece≈ø≈øity as ≈øome men plead for, that it is contrary to the perceptions of the human mind,‚Äîwe have a con≈øciou≈øne≈øs of liberty, we perceive no external influence, we have a moral ≈øen≈øe, we pa≈øs a judgment on our own actions, approve or di≈øapprove our≈øelves and others. It ≈øhows the difficulty, to which a very ≈øen≈øible writer E≈ø≈øays on the principles of morality and natural religion. of the pre≈øent day is reduced, who allows this inward perception, that we are nece≈ø≈øitated to think our≈øelves and others free; and yet denies the reality of liberty. God has, according to him, implanted a delu≈øive ≈øen≈øe in us, our feeling is deceitful, the God of truth doth continually by a po≈øitive influence deceive and delude us. What ≈øtrange notions have ≈øome men of that glorious being, all who≈øe ways are truth, and who is righteous altogether! Is it not better to ≈øet limits to our enquiries, and to ≈øuppo≈øe there may be a mi≈øtake in ≈øome curious ≈øpeculations, than to entertain ≈øentiments ≈øo di≈øhonorable to God, and ≈øo entirely ≈øubver≈øive of all moral government?

div.p: IF from what has been ≈øaid it ≈øhould appear, that Mr. Edwards's ≈øcheme of nece≈ø≈øity may ju≈øtly be charged with making an holy and good God the proper cau≈øe of ≈øin, (which is the leading objection we have all along had to his book on the will) it can be to every little purpo≈øe to alledge texts of ≈øcripture in ≈øupport of it. A doctrine ≈øo repugnant to our natural apprehen≈øions of God and his providence cannot be ≈øupported by any pretence of authority from him. The holy ≈øcriptures were not given to contradict and ≈øubvert tho≈øe notions of his moral perfections and government, which God hath given us by rea≈øon and the light of nature; but to confirm and improve them, as well as to afford us important in≈øtruction in things which una≈ø≈øi≈øted rea≈øon would never have di≈øcovered. If any, therefore, ≈øhould bring this doctrine to us, that God is the cau≈øe of moral evil, the direction given to the I≈øraelites, in the ca≈øe of being enticed to idolatry, Deut. xiii. 1,‚Äî4. is for our learning, and may ≈øerve to regulate our conduct.
