The enquiry is not pur≈øued to the end, the foundation of the will's determination is not di≈øcovered. What it is that gives cau≈øal influence to motive, or wherein its energy
con≈øi≈øts, remains ≈øtill to be pointed out. But it was endeavored to be proved, in the next place, by various con≈øiderations, and particularly from Mr. Edwards's own authority and rea≈øoning, that in truth the ≈øtronge≈øt motive is not the moral cau≈øe of volition, and that there is no nece≈ø≈øary coincidence between the one and the other. And la≈øtly, that volition is not the proper cau≈øe of external action, any more than the highe≈øt motive is of volition.

After the mention of ≈øome preliminary principles, it was enquired, under the next head of the propo≈øed examination, whether the wills of moral agents are nece≈ø≈øarily determined by an extrin≈øic, or by an intrin≈øic cau≈øe, and whether there can be natural liberty without moral, on Mr. Edwards's ≈øcheme. This ≈øcheme was repre≈øented as making God the author of ≈øin, by plain and direct con≈øequence‚Äîthe ≈øuppo≈øed advantage of ≈øin to the univer≈øe was briefly noticed; and general ob≈øervations & reflections ≈øubjoined, with a view to make it manife≈øt, that if no being can, or ever could, chu≈øe or act otherwi≈øe in any ca≈øe, 'tis very immaterial by what name this nece≈ø≈øity is called, ≈øince a nece≈ø≈øity more ab≈øolute cannot be conceived of‚Äîthat the runing up moral events, like natural, through a chain of ≈øecond cau≈øes to the fir≈øt, is confounding the agency of intelligent creatures with mechani≈øm‚Äîmaking their volitions and conduct the agency of the Deity, properly ≈øpeaking‚Äîor rather, that, upon the principles of Mr. Edwards, the Deity him≈øelf is not an agent, but an in≈øtrument of nece≈ø≈øity and fate. There is no ≈øelf-mover‚Äîdirection‚Äîdetermination, or ≈øource of activity, in the univer≈øe. Wherein our author profe≈ø≈øeth him≈øelf a friend of liberty, he either contradicts his own principles, or allows of no liberty that is of any moment, or at all connected with moral agency.

We endeavoured, under the la≈øt branch of our general de≈øign, to exhibit a ≈øcheme more con≈øonant to rea≈øon and truth; ≈øhewing from the di≈øcernment that di≈øtingui≈øheth moral agents from the brute-creation, and their capacity of chu≈øing and acting otherwi≈øe than they in fact do, that internal moral liberty and ≈øelf-determination belong to them‚Äîthat it no way interferes with this liberty to admit the exhibition and influence of motives in moral volitions.
The ≈øcheme of nece≈ø≈øity exhibited in Mr. Edwards's book, if true in ≈øpeculation, was, upon the whole, ≈øhewn to be fal≈øe in its practical application‚Äîof mo≈øt dangerous tendency and con≈øequence. A ≈øpecimen was al≈øo annexed of Mr. Edwards's agreeing, in his leading ≈øentiments, with antient and modern fatali≈øts.

This is a view of the ≈øubject ≈øo far as it was con≈øidered in our former publication. In the pre≈øent, the ≈øame general de≈øign has been re≈øumed and continued. A further proof of ≈øelf-determination hath been adduced from the capacity in moral agents of deliberating, ≈øu≈øpending, &c.‚Äî the di≈øtinction of rational agency from animal has been ≈øtated‚Äîa di≈øtinction entirely confounded in Mr. Edwards's book, which has been further ≈øhewn to contain a full denial of moral liberty. It has been argued, that events in the moral world are not uniform, as in the material‚Äîthat the Deity mu≈øt be the efficient cau≈øe of moral evil, or it hath no ≈øuch cau≈øe, unle≈øs ≈øelf-determination be admitted‚Äî that motives do not nece≈ø≈øitate, nor are the cau≈øe of volition, which hath a moral per≈øon or agent for its cau≈øe. The di≈øtinction of natural and moral nece≈ø≈øity hath been particularly attended to, and, in Mr. Edwards's u≈øe of it, ≈øhewn to be groundle≈øs; ≈øince, if he means any thing, a ≈øtrict and ab≈øolute nece≈ø≈øity is equally intended by the former as by the latter‚Äîwe have touched the argument from the nece≈ø≈øity of the divine moral rectitude, and pre≈øume it was made to appear, that there is no infering herefrom a ≈øtrict nece≈ø≈øity in the moral volitions and actions of creatures. From Mr. Edwards's notion of nece≈ø≈øity, it follows, that God is the author or cau≈øe of ≈øin, or it hath no cau≈øe. This ≈øame conclu≈øion has further been ≈øhewn to follow from his plan of the origin of evil, which we have di≈øtinctly examined‚Äîa plan which, indeed, renders the exi≈øtence of ≈øin forever impo≈ø≈øible. His hypothe≈øis, which derives moral evil from the withdraw of divine influence and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, has been ≈øhewn not to differ materially, either from theirs who explicitly a≈øcribe it to divine efficiency, or from theirs who ≈øuppo≈øe God might make creatures originally vicious. The only con≈øi≈øtent hypothe≈øis is that which derives evil from the abu≈øe of moral liberty. The di≈øtinction of the e≈ø≈øence of
virtue and vice from their cau≈øe, has, we flatter our≈øelves, been evinced to be futile and eva≈øive, by no means to an≈øwer Mr. Edwards's purpo≈øe, however important he e≈øteemed it, and how much ≈øoever his principles required it. It has been con≈øidered, whether moral evil is indeed be≈øt for the world; or ≈øuppo≈øe it is, whether it be be≈øt that God ≈øhould effect it by his agency. We have al≈øo examined the argument from divine pre≈øcience, and particularly ≈øhewn, that the certainty of moral events is altogether different from nece≈ø≈øity, the former not affecting their nature, or the manner of their coming to pa≈øs, or any way influencing them, as the latter doth‚Äîthat pre≈øcience ≈øtands not in the relation of cau≈øe to the things foreknown. Texts of ≈øcripture u≈øually alledged in ≈øupport of the ≈øcheme of nece≈ø≈øity have been ≈øhewn to be mi≈øcon≈øtrued. A reply has been made to ≈øome principal objections, and a di≈ø≈øertation added on metaphy≈øical rea≈øoning, ≈øhewing that it rather ≈øerves to bewilder than elucidate the pre≈øent ≈øubject. We have, therefore, made but little u≈øe of it; although it has in ≈øome mea≈øure been evinced, (as we ≈øuppo≈øe) in the cour≈øe of our examination, that the metaphy≈øician is ea≈øily repul≈øed with his own weapons.

In the examination ≈øome arguments were touched, among many which occur'd, evincing the a≈øpect Mr. Edwards's ≈øcheme hath on the moral perfections and government of God, and its con≈øequent practical tendency. Other arguments have been now mentioned with the ≈øame view. The oppo≈øite truth was there exhibited in part; we have now further explain'd our≈øelves, and pur≈øued the de≈øign before opened, as far as appeared needful at pre≈øent. To ≈øave the trouble of repetition, we have ≈øeveral times refered the reader to things ≈øaid in the examination.

Our aim has been to attend to the principal point in debate, not to dwell on le≈ø≈øer and circum≈øtantial things. If the former hath been kept in view, it may be rea≈øonably reque≈øted, that if any gentleman ≈øhall think it needful to publi≈øh remarks on what we have written, he will not make incidental things a principal object of attention. To divert his own or the reader's mind from what is mo≈øt material would be alike inju≈øtice to both, as well as uncandid to
the examiner. The main objection to Mr. Edwards's ≈øcheme is, that he argues for a nece≈ø≈øity which can be defended on this only hypothe≈øis, that God is the cau≈øe of ≈øin. To this ≈øingle que≈øtion, the whole controver≈øy is reducible. Whoever would defend his book mu≈øt either ≈øhew, that the leading principles of it do not ≈øuppo≈øe the deity to be the efficient of moral evil; or el≈øe that ≈øuch a ≈øuppo≈øition is no reproach to his character and government. We dare affirm he is not the efficient cau≈øe of moral evil; yea, ≈øhould we pre≈øume to affirm that he is this cau≈øe, it would, we doubt not in the lea≈øt, be ≈øtriking at the foundation of all religion.

The pulic attention and candor would now have been a≈øked no longer, had it not been the opinion of a number of re≈øpectable gentlemen, that we are called upon to take ≈øome notice of the "e≈ø≈øay on moral agency" &c. through which are inter≈øper≈øed remarks on what we wrote before, and in ≈øome parts of which the author has conde≈øcended more profe≈ø≈øedly to attend to the examination. Our ≈øtrictures on this e≈ø≈øay ≈øhall be di≈øpatched with all convenient brevity.

div.head: STRICTURES on "an e≈ø≈øay on moral agency:" (So called) Containing remarks on a late anonymous publication, entitled, An examination of the late Rev'd Pre≈øident Edwards's enquiry on freedom of will. By Stephen We≈øt, A. M. Pa≈øtor of the church in Stockbridge.
div.p: THIS e≈ø≈øay contains ≈øcarce any thing new. But few arguments are advanced in it, except ≈øuch as Mr. Edwards had made u≈øe of, and handled with more appearance of rea≈øon. In examining Mr. Edwards, we have ≈øufficiently replied to the mo≈øt material things in Mr. We≈øt. Mr. We≈øt, in denying original righteou≈øne≈øs, departs, indeed, from Mr. Edwards. Compare part I. ≈øect. 1, 2. of Mr. We≈øt's e≈ø≈øay (particularly p. 53.) with Edwards p. 43. There is al≈øo a verbal difference between the≈øe two gentlemen re≈øpecting the agency of the Deity in ≈øin. While Mr. Edwards denies (in words) a po≈øitive divine influence or efficiency in moral evil, Mr. We≈øt expre≈øsly maintains it, and argues (in his manner) for it, through a number of ≈øections, in the ≈øecond part of his e≈ø≈øay. This, however, is no more than Mr. Edwards's doctrine amounts to, as hath been ≈øhewn. We purpo≈øe to re≈øume this point after taking notice of ≈øome other things in the e≈ø≈øay before us, and ≈øome exceptions to our former publication.

In the ≈øection on power, we conjecture that Mr. We≈øt hath applied this word improperly, as a philo≈øopher and as a morali≈øt. The word, as u≈øed in mechanics, is never applied, by any philo≈øopher we have had opportunity to read, in the manner Mr. We≈øt applies it, to the body moved; but
uniformly and con≈øtantly to the mover. Compare p. 37, 38. of Mr. We≈øt's e≈ø≈øay with Pemberton's view of Sir I≈øaac Newton's philo≈øophy, p. 31. ¬ß 8, 9. p. 82. ¬ß 51. Martin on mechanics, pa≈ø≈øim. Ozanam's cur≈øus mathematicus, vol. 4. part I. pa≈ø≈øim. Chambers in tit. Lever. Were the≈øe philo≈øophers utter ≈øtrangers to the laws of nature. (E≈ø≈øay p. 40.) From this arbitrary u≈øe of the word power, this philo≈øophy fal≈øely ≈øo called, he proceeds to make his deduction, that the word, in its application to human nature, imports only a capacity of being the ≈øubject of certain effects from divine operation‚Äî 'tis "a power to be wrought upon, not a power to operate." (P. 43.)

Admitting his application of the word power to mechanics had been philo≈øophical, what is the inference? that moral agency and mechani≈øm are the ≈øame? So it ≈øeems. But this, we ≈øuppo≈øe, Mr. We≈øt would not be fond of maintaining; becau≈øe he appears to di≈øapprove Lord Kaim's opinion recited p. 128.‚ÄîAnd becau≈øe he [Mr. We≈øt] hath attempted to ≈øhew, that his own ≈øcheme does not make mankind machines. Part I. ≈øect. 7. Moreover, in this ≈øame ≈øection on power, he informs us, that he is "far from apprehending" that his beforementioned u≈øe of the word power is the only ≈øen≈øe in which it may be u≈øed with propriety, as applied to moral agents‚Äîto men. It may doubtle≈øs be u≈øed with propriety to indicate‚Äî≈øomething wherein man is a moral agent, and on account of which he is a fit ≈øubject of prai≈øe or blame, commendation or cen≈øure. P. 42. The word power, then, as above applied to human nature, points out no abilities properly in men‚Äînothing wherein they are moral agents.

P. 44. He attempts to illu≈øtrate that idea of power, which indicateth and denoteth ≈øome ability properly in men‚Äî≈øomething wherein man is a moral agent, and in which there is de≈øert of prai≈øe or blame, &c. What is this power or ability, which is e≈ø≈øential to moral agency? We are told it is "voluntary exertion." Whatever external action‚Äîtakes place upon our willing it, is in our power. (P.46.) Whatever event or action doth not follow the election of the mind, is not in our power.‚Äî Yet in the next paragraph, Mr. We≈øt ≈øaith, Power, in this "con≈øtruction of it, is not e≈ø≈øential to moral agency."

The≈øe things require no very critical animadver≈øions. When the word power is applied to human nature in Mr. We≈øt's fir≈øt ≈øen≈øe, it points out nothing wherein men are moral agents. When it is u≈øed in his ≈øecond ≈øen≈øe, it is not e≈ø≈øential to moral agency. The con≈øequence is plain, that men are not moral agents, having no power or ability that indicateth moral agency. We are clear with Mr. We≈øt, that power, in either of the ≈øen≈øes he u≈øeth it, doth not denote moral agency. The mind may be free, and exert it≈øelf with great ≈øtrength, without any of the la≈øt-mentioned "power." And in the fir≈øt-mentioned ≈øen≈øe, it indicateth nothing wherein man is a moral agent. A power or liberty with reference to external actions only is allowed to human nature by ≈øome gentlemen, who yet grant, that virtue and vice lie in the frame of the heart. Liberty ≈øay they, is e≈ø≈øential to moral agency. What liberty? External? no; for an intelligent creature may be holy or ≈øinful without ≈øuch liberty. Internal? no; for in re≈øpect to inward volitions & di≈øpo≈øitions, they have not a power to operate, but only a power to be wrought upon. (P.43.) We appeal to common ≈øen≈øe whether ≈øuch a ≈øcheme leaves any room to a≈øcribe liberty or agency to mankind? Whether it doth not wholly confound moral agency with mechani≈øm? For who ever attributed liberty or agency to the meer ≈øubject and in≈øtrument of a foreign operation and action? As well might the ≈øaw, ax, or ≈øtaff in the hands of any man be called agents. Is this the re≈øult of a careful and ≈øtrict examination and explanation of the powers of human nature? Is it a little peculiar, that in an e≈ø≈øay profe≈ø≈øedly wrote on "moral agency," the ≈øubject it≈øelf has been kept wholy out of ≈øight?

The two fir≈øt ≈øections we have now publi≈øhed ≈øeem to ≈øuper≈øede the occa≈øion for a particular reply to Mr. We≈øt's on moral agency and power. We refer him there for further ≈øatisfaction. We only remark, that as there appears to us no difference between ≈øuppo≈øing God to be the cau≈øe of ≈øin by his action on the creature after made, and ≈øuppo≈øing an intelligent being to be made ≈øinful by him at fir≈øt; ≈øo, if we under≈øtand Mr. We≈øt, he means to make no difference,
but a≈ø≈øerts both. Mr. Edwards rather cho≈øe to expre≈øs him≈øelf in ≈øuch manner as leads the reader to conclude his opinion was, that God is the mediate cau≈øe of ≈øin; Mr. We≈øt maintains that he is the immediate cau≈øe of it. Indeed he ob≈øerves, "the whole and only difference" between an immediate and mediate dependance is, that, in the one ca≈øe, the cau≈øe‚Äîoperates through one or a number of means‚Äîin the other, its tendency and influence are immediately ≈øeen, and it doth not operate through any medium. It is quite unphilo≈øophical (not to ≈øay athei≈øtical) to ≈øuffer any number of intervening media to ob≈øcure the agency of that divine hand, which God is lifting up, and making vi≈øible in all his works. P. 96. We hence conclude, that Mr. We≈øt will not except to our rea≈øoning, ≈øection ≈øecond, that it makes no material difference whether the Deity is ≈øuppo≈øed to be the mediate or immediate cau≈øe of ≈øin and moral turpitude. And when he ≈øhall ≈øhew, that God is the cau≈øe of every act of will in the creatures, ≈øhould the examiner be in≈øtrumental to continue the di≈øpute, he would contradict his own opinion, expre≈ø≈øed p. 6. of the examination.

P. 140. Mr. We≈øt concedes, that what Mr. Edwards hath ≈øaid on the ≈øubject of motives is liable to ≈øome of the exceptions which the examiner hath taken again≈øt it. Yet he is "humbly of opinion if" what he hath offered in his own e≈ø≈øay were properly con≈øidered, we ≈øhould not find the appearance of ≈øuch incon≈øi≈øtency and ab≈øurdity ‚Äîas the examiner would per≈øuade the public‚Äîmay be fa≈øtened upon Mr. Edwards. P. 72. The examiner, with many others, would have been glad to have ≈øeen this appearance of incon≈øi≈øtency removed. Notwith≈øtanding the "carefulne≈øs" Mr. W. has taken in examining and explaining the nature and influence of motives, Part I. ≈øect. 3. the ≈øubject remains entangled. The word motive importeth, ≈øaith he, nothing different from the real choice of the mind‚ÄîWhen motive is con≈øidered as cau≈øe or antecedent, its correlative is outward action‚ÄîMotives are never to have cau≈øal influence or efficiency attributed to them. There is al≈øo another ≈øen≈øe in which the word motive is u≈øed. Sometimes,
≈øaith he, it is u≈øed, neither for volition, nor the cau≈øe of volition; but merely for the external object which doth, or ought to, engage the affection, and terminate the choice.‚ÄîThus, the motives of the go≈øpel mean the rea≈øons exhibited in the go≈øpel, why men ought to for≈øake their ≈øins, and turn unto God. Multitudes have the≈øe rea≈øons (motives) full in view; and yet utterly refu≈øe and neglect to return. As ≈øuppo≈øe motives of intere≈øt, honor, profit, extant in the mind's view at the ≈øame time with the motives of the go≈øpel; the former govern to the neglect and refu≈øal of the latter. The inferior perceived motive determines the mind's choice to the rejection of the ≈øuperior. For are motives "exhibited and full in view," and yet not apparent to or perceived by the mind to which they are exhibited, and in who≈øe view they ≈øtand? If they are perceived, then how can it be that the highe≈øt motive always determines volition? Are not tho≈øe motives, which ought to govern, highe≈øt, if full in the view? Yet multitudes utterly neglect and refu≈øe them. On the other hand, if they are not apparent or perceived, then how are they exhibited to, and full in view of the mind? how refu≈øed or neglected? Mr. We≈øt in≈øi≈øts, that motives influence the mind only as the mind is in actual motion in the perception of them. But if perception and choice be the ≈øame, how then do motives influence volition? how have they a tendency to it? Do they influence, have they a tendency, to that which is actually effected? After volition has taken place, 'tis too late for their influence and tendency. But perhaps what follows may clear up this difficulty: Though no tendency of motives to volition is perceived and felt, otherwi≈øe than in the actual taking place and exertion of choice; yet there is a foundation in the nature of things, ari≈øing from ≈øome certain quality in objects, and from the particular ≈øtate, temper and complexion of the mind, for their being cho≈øen as ≈øoon as they ≈øhall come into the view of the mind. (The reader will remember he had ju≈øt been ≈øpeaking of motives full in view, but utterly refu≈øed.) Apply this to the evangelical motives to repentance. With re≈øpect to tho≈øe who≈øe "≈øtate, temper and complexion of mind," antecedently
corre≈øpond to the≈øe motives, they have a tendency to lead to repentance: But with re≈øpect to tho≈øe in whom there is not this antecedent corre≈øpondence of temper, they have not this tendency in the lea≈øt. There is no foundation for a tendency in go≈øpel motives to engage men's choice, unle≈øs the ≈øtate and temper of their minds corre≈øpond to the≈øe motives, antecedent to the exhibition of them. Now will Mr. We≈øt ≈øay, that there is this corre≈øpondence of temper in any unregenerate per≈øon? We tru≈øt he will not. The con≈øequence will then be, that that change, which the go≈øpel hath a tendency and is de≈øigned to produce in men, mu≈øt be actually effected before it's motives are exhibited‚Äîthe end mu≈øt be accompli≈øhed before the means are applied‚Äî≈øinners mu≈øt for≈øake their ≈øins and turn to God, and then the go≈øpel motives will have a tendency to lead them to repentance; but not before. The go≈øpel then is no tender to the unregenerate. And if not to them, who are tho≈øe "multitudes" to whom its motives are exhibited, and who "utterly refu≈øe and neglect" them, though "full in their view?"

Such a notion of tendency and influence in motives is very ≈øingular. When did any writer before Mr. We≈øt ever u≈øe the term motives in this ≈øen≈øe? that the thing motives are de≈øigned to engage to mu≈øt be effected before the exibition and perception of them? that motives obtain this appellation from the mind's being in actual motion? that motives full in view are utterly neglected and refu≈øed? We are quite content the public ≈øhould judge, whether Mr. We≈øt's attempt to reconcile Mr. Edwards with him≈øelf has removed the appearance of incon≈øi≈øtency and ab≈øurdity, or hath not rather confu≈øed and jumbled ≈øtill more the ≈øubject of the determination of the will by motives. In what ≈øen≈øe the influence of motives in moral volitions may be admitted, we have endeavoured to ≈øhew Part III. ≈øect. 2. of the examination, and ≈øection 2d. of the pre≈øent continuation thereof.

P. 24; 76,‚Äî79. Quotations are made in abundance from the examiner to prove him gro≈øsly incon≈øi≈øtent with him≈øelf, and that he hath given in ample te≈øtimony to the truth of the doctrine he oppo≈øeth. Had Mr. We≈øt properly
con≈øidered that at p. 92. he quotes the examiner as admitting, that every moral event mu≈øt have a cau≈øe, and ≈øaying, that moral agents are the cau≈øes of their own actions, he would not, perhaps, have given him≈øelf the trouble to copy ≈øo much from the examination. We do maintain that the ≈øubjects of moral volitions are al≈øo the cau≈øe of their own volitions. This is a different thing from ≈øaying, that volition is its own cau≈øe. The di≈øtinction between the terms volition and agent is plain. Agents determine them≈øelves; we ≈øay not that the properties or actions of agents are ≈øelf-determined‚Äîthat volition, which is already become effect, is the cau≈øe of it's own exi≈øtence. Mr. We≈øt had no occa≈øion to repre≈øent the examiner's doctrine in this light. And though he ≈øuppo≈øeth that an enquiry into the cau≈øe of volition belongs not to the ≈øubject of moral agency, yet we pre≈øume enough hath been ≈øaid, particularly in the 5th ≈øection, to ≈øhew that it doth. In the ≈øame part of Mr. We≈øt's e≈ø≈øay, the examiner is cen≈øured pretty ≈øeverely for not allowing more weight to a particular di≈øtinction of Mr. Edwards's, and treating it with contempt. "Upon a review of the matter," Mr. We≈øt thinks the examiner him≈øelf will be convinced that he hath not herein done ju≈øtice to Mr. Edwards.

The examiner hath "reviewed the matter," and is "convinced" of no other "inju≈øtice herein done" by him "to Mr. Edwards," than that he did not ≈øufficiently expo≈øe the weakne≈øs of the di≈øtinction refered to. While he a≈øks pardon for this omi≈ø≈øion, he hopes he has made ≈øome atonement for it by taking the trouble to write an whole ≈øection profe≈ø≈øedly on the point. Herein he hath al≈øo an≈øwered to another exception of Mr. We≈øt's a few lines below on the ≈øame page; (p. 83.) and in his turn mu≈øt fault Mr. We≈øt for an unfair repre≈øentation of him. The reader by turning to the page in the examination, which Mr. We≈øt refers to, will ≈øee the repre≈øentation is partial.

In what Mr. We≈øt hath offered, in divers parts of his e≈ø≈øay, in a critical way, on the antecedent ≈øtate of the mind and volition, he appears ≈ølow in under≈øtanding the examiner, and doth not repre≈øent him to ≈øuch advantage as might have been done con≈øi≈øtently enough with ≈øound critici≈øm.
Part I. ≈øect. 8. Mr. We≈øt hath more profe≈ø≈øedly remarked on the examiner, and accu≈øeth him as having injured both Mr. Edwards and the truth.
